repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body: This PR fixes bugs that will allow to add Windows tests to GitHub Actions workflow in PR #4324

comment_data.body:
1) This looks to me like an abuse of `needs_cpp_construction` when you're really just trying to detect if we're building in C++. I get why it's convenient, but `needs_cpp_construction` is only really about whether to generate C++ constructor and destructor code which doesn't seem relevant here (i.e. I'd rather not have to buffers just because I've changed something about how destructors are called in a cdef class).

    I think you can get the value of `cpp` from `code.funcstate` or `code.globalstate` somewhere.

2) Is this a problem with older MSVC versions? `offsetof(struct StructName, memberName)` seems fine in recent versions.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -679,8 +679,14 @@ def get_type_information_cname(code, dtype, maxdepth=None):
                      for f in fields]
             typecode.putln("static __Pyx_StructField %s[] = {" % structinfo_name, safe=True)
             for f, typeinfo in zip(fields, types):
+                if dtype.needs_cpp_construction:
+                    # for cpp: offsetof(StrucName, memberName)
+                    struct_type = dtype.cname

comment_data.body:
> 2\. Is this a problem with older MSVC versions?

What version do you use?
Github actions and my local installation detects this as an error.

comment_data.body: https://godbolt.org/z/anEch1f3K (unless there's some detail that I missed). That lets you go back to MSVC 2015, and it seems fine there. I didn't go further.

comment_data.body:
Well, the problem is not really the `offsetof(struct StrucName, memberName)`, but probably the surrounding of this code.
You can look [here](https://github.com/0dminnimda/cython/runs/3214687998#step:5:2416)

I didn't go deep into the problem then, and just that change fixed the problem, I'll now try to find out in more detail what was the matter.

comment_data.body:
> 1. I think you can get the value of `cpp` from `code.funcstate` or `code.globalstate` somewhere.

AFAIU, we compile this piece of code only in the specified language, so probably, yes, it will do.

comment_data.body: The original code was added [here](https://github.com/cython/cython/commit/20a4a188e90cac5fe870cde73ada7b7173a78e55#diff-36a782bc4ad684402e6bf0b6e257873a323407a7b7c80a00b4cbbc19f6cc3a73R1153) and used [`__Pyx_FIELD_OFFSET`](https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/20a4a188e90cac5fe870cde73ada7b7173a78e55/Cython/Compiler/Buffer.py#L716) (now deprecated), which did not cause such errors. A bug was added during the transition from `__Pyx_FIELD_OFFSET` to `offsetof`.

comment_data.body: But in the end, my few tests with `__Pyx_FIELD_OFFSET`  show that there is no difference between `__Pyx_FIELD_OFFSET(struct StrucName const, memberName)` and `offsetof(struct StrucName, memberName)` for msvc

comment_data.body:
> Should we even have this const inside offsetof?

I don't think so. You could probably do `if dtype.is_cv_qualified: dtype = dtype.cv_base_type` (and do it whether you're in C or in C++ mode)

Yes, I think it will do

commit.message: Fix bugs with Windows and complete `write_file` and `write_newer_file` (cythonGH-4329)
Buffer.py: format a bit + use is_cv_qualified for `struct_type` definition

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Fix bugs with Windows
